column5:
I feel like such a minority when I tell myself how much I'm enjoying this time. I'm WFH and being able to do other tasks during the work day in between, rather than rushing home after a full day of work and cramming necessary things in a couple hours before bed has been amazing. My mental health and physical health have improved. And who doesn't want to spend the day with their pup all the time.

I'm not looking forward to returning to the rat race after all this. I'm trying to soak up every second. Getting to enjoy hobbies and relax at a slower pace. 

It's sad that it took this type of devestating event to experience this. And obviously there are 100s of thousands of people who are on the very opposite spectrum or have no choice but to report in to work. So I'm not trying to negate their experiences. I'm very fortunate.

Waiting til Iâ€™m ready to leave work after an 8hr day, in my office, on the unit, and a patient â€œneedsâ€ to use the phone to call someone. Thereâ€™s patient phone on the unit they couldâ€™ve used all day...or they wait until 5min before I leave and mention something that changes their entire discharge plan.

And while this isnâ€™t a last minute request, itâ€™s certainly recurrent: having to take verbal abuse from patients because theyâ€™re mad about things I have no control over but Iâ€™m just available to them on the unit.

Being at a psych hospital, we arenâ€™t allowed to discharge to the streets. So weâ€™ve to scramble trying to find shelters or in many cases send patients to shelters out of their county because they countyâ€™s shelter has many hospital discharge policies in place or donâ€™t exist...itâ€™s so infuriating at times.

I too work at a hospital. I get patients all the time saying they lied about being suicidal in order to come inpatient because they want housing. They arenâ€™t happy when I tell them that weâ€™re a hospital and so therefore, we do not provide or find housing.

This includes the family members who when we call say, they need housing, or they need â€˜structured housingâ€™, I.e. if the patient stuck to a schedule and kept busy theyâ€™d be alright. They donâ€™t like it either when I tell them the secret....it doesnâ€™t exist. (Unless of course youâ€™re  very mentally Ill and weâ€™re talking about CRR or LTSR)

One that you state you regret and didnâ€™t think was wrong from the get go as you left the important piece in the office to just repair â€œthe shellâ€. In my hospital the nurses tend to complain a lot more, and more openly to whom everâ€™s around to hear. They definitely show signs of burnout. But itâ€™s frustrating to hear the complaining daily because they get better pay than the social worker department and they have a union that supports them. So for us in social work who are constantly frustrated with doctors, outpatient agencies, and having to cohesively work with our units/treatment teams/and the patients, it adds on me personally to my frustrations and feelings of burn out.
